quizInfo.Subject: Information Assurance and Security
quizInfo.Title: Midterms Reviewer Pro Max: [All Midterm Topics]

quizData.question: What cipher shifts each letter in the plaintext by a certain number down the alphabet?
What cipher is named after a Roman general who used it to communicate with generals?
What cipher begins by choosing a keyword and removing repeated letters?
What cipher was described by a papal secretary of ciphers in 1580?
What cipher uses a key letter such as 'P' to align the keyword with plaintext?
What cipher performs permutation on plaintext letters instead of substitution?
What cipher improves on monoalphabetic ciphers by using different substitutions through the message?
What describes a company's security controls and activities?
What is the primary way in which administration prospects for security are translated into specific, measurable goals?
What applies to all employees, stockholders, consultants, and service providers who use company assets?
Who usually develops standards around the usage of the computer system?
Who ensures the legal points in the document and guides appropriateness?
Who obtains a certificate from employees to ensure they understood the policy?
Who must review policies based on the businessâ€™s condition?
Who should understand the security policy to fulfill their roles?
What has three types: Drafted on paper, in employeesâ€™ minds, and implemented?
What mandates protection for facilities such as doors, entry points, and alarms?
What instructs employees how to securely conduct daily business activities?
What directs admins on what technology to use and how to apply controls?
What compares the actual practice with the security policy?
What ensures compliance with the principles dictated by the company?
What identifies employees as soft targets that can be compromised?
What must include communication and reminders on what not to reveal?
What term describes employees as the easiest to exploit?
Who are either 'disgruntle' or become framed to provide info about a company?
What provides short-term access to sensitive data to unauthorized individuals?
What lists key recurring tasks for network administrators?
What must include an overview of all system risks including human and technical errors?
What encourages documentation at every step and helps future auditors?
What allows secure connection to office networks using staff laptops?
What walks through alternative command setup processes for popular servers?
What combines professional training with technical resilience to combat phishing?
What involves trying to break into systems to test their security?
What enables detection and correction of trends that lead to network issues?
What is the science of secret writing used to keep data secure?
What term means secret or hidden?
What is the science and art of breaking cryptosystems?
What term refers to the study of writing and solving codes?
What uses one secret key and is faster than other cryptography types?
What uses public and private keys and is slow for decrypting bulk messages?
What converts plain-text to a fixed-size value using a function?
What type of cryptanalysis attack uses all possible key combinations?
What attack involves tricking someone into giving sensitive information?
What attack exploits physical access to obtain a secret key?
What refers to any group of users, workstations, devices, printers, computers, and database servers that share different types of data via network resources?
What is used to manage all user functions, including username, password, and shared system resource authentication and access?
What is used to assign specific resource privileges such as user accounts?
What comprises combined systems, servers, and workgroups?
What governs all basic domain functions and manages network security?
In a simple network domain, what are directly connected?
Depending on network requirements, what may exist in one domain?
Which domain covers all the users that have access to the other domains?
Which domain covers all the users that have access to the other domains?
In which domain can a user destroy data in the app and delete everything?
A user inserting an infected flash drive into the computer is a risk in which domain?
A user using their password to delete their files is a risk in which domain?
Which domain consists of the computer of an individual user where production takes place?
The OS having known software vulnerabilities that allow hackers to connect remotely and steal data is a risk in which domain?
The browser having known software vulnerabilities that allow unsigned scripts to install malware silently is a risk in which domain?
The hard drive failing and losing data is a risk in which domain?
Which domain contains all the workstations, hubs, switches, and routers?
Work spreading through the network and infecting all computers is a risk in which domain?
LAN server OS having known software vulnerabilities is a risk in which domain?
Unauthorized users accessing organization workstations in LANs is a risk in which domain?
Which domain consists of the internet and semi-private lines?
A major network outage from the service provider is a risk in which domain?
A server receiving DOS or DDOS attacks is a risk in which domain?
A File Transfer Protocol (FTP) allowing anonymously uploaded illegal software is a risk in which domain?
Which domain serves as the boundary between trusted and untrusted zones?
Hackers penetrating the IT infrastructure to gain access to the internal network is a risk in which domain?
Firewalls with unnecessary ports open allowing access from the internet is a risk in which domain?
Which domain is made up of user-accessed servers such as email and database?
Fires destroying primary data is a risk in which domain?
DOS attacks crippling the organization’s email is a risk in which domain?
A database server being attacked by SQL injection that corrupts data is a risk in which domain?
Which domain allows a mobile user to access the local network usually through a VPN?
Communication circuit outage denying connection is a risk in which domain?
Remote communication from the office being unsecured is a risk in which domain?
What type of user has their username and password stored in the computer itself?
When logging in as this type of user, the computer checks its passwords file to see if they are allowed to log in.
Which type of user has their username and password stored on a domain controller rather than the computer?
When logging in as this type of user, the computer asks the domain controller with privileges assigned to the user.
This type of user system evolved in response to the administration challenge of managing large numbers of computers, devices, services, and users.
Which domain is a subnetwork made up of servers and clients controlled by a centralized database?
In which domain is user approval obtained through a central server or domain controller?
Which domain consists of a network that spans a large geographic area such as cities or countries?
A network that can be private to connect parts of a business or public to connect smaller networks is known as what domain?
Which domain enables remote users to access files on any devices connected to the network at any time?
This domain increases productivity and allows better collaboration around the world by allowing remote users access to files.
Which domain allows organizations the flexibility to hire the best talent regardless of location?
Which domain allows technical support to connect to user computers from remote locations to help reduce issues?
What is the common method of providing remote access?
What technology creates a safe and encrypted connection over a less secure network like the internet?
Which method was developed to enable remote users and branch offices to log into corporate apps and resources securely?
Which remote access technology is commonly in use today?
In which VPN must a client be installed in the end user’s computer and configured with target network details like the gateway IP address and a pre-shared security key?
Which VPN method typically includes licenses for connections when a firewall is purchased?
Which VPN method has low processing overhead for the firewall, allowing many connections to be active at the same time?
What is an established VPN technology that many people are already familiar with?
Which VPN method requires a software client to be installed and configured in the target device before a connection is established, causing difficulties if a worker is not in the office?
Which encryption technology is commonly used to secure communication on the internet?
In which VPN method does the network admin publish the VPN client to the firewall, allowing it to be downloaded via the firewall’s public connection?
Which VPN method allows end users to install the VPN client from a public portal?
In which VPN method does the IT department not need to manually configure each machine that requires remote access?
Which VPN method allows network administrators to set up granular security policies for specific corporate network resources?
Which VPN method provides software clients for mobile devices, allowing users to view corporate intranet without using a computer?
Which VPN method requires more firewall configuration to publish the client network?
Which VPN method requires more processing overhead for the firewall, limiting the number of client connections it can handle?
What VPN licenses are usually sold as an add-on to hardware because some firewalls cannot handle too many client connections?
Which remote access method is a relatively new approach developed by Microsoft?
Which method creates an “always on” secure connection at the OS level?
Which remote access method allows users to connect without needing to install or run anything?
Which remote access method is described as seamless technology that could change the way users work remotely?
Which remote access method requires elaborate changes to the corporate network?
Which remote access method is designed with IPv6 as the primary addressing scheme and IPv4 secondarily?
Which remote access method requires additional software on the LAN so remote users can access IPv4 addresses?
Which domain consists of all of a business’ mission-critical systems, apps, and data?
Which domain must be secured at all times to prevent loss of large amounts of sensitive information and productivity disruption?
Commonly targeted systems and apps in which domain include OSes, email apps and servers, ERP apps and systems, and web browsers?
Attacks on which domain are categorized into denial or destruction, alteration, and disclosure?
Gaining access to a physical entity or area without permission is known as what?
What type of access allows a malicious individual to steal, alter, or destroy systems and data if gained?
Which type of unauthorized access is nearly identical to unauthorized physical access but is not limited to tangible data?
Which type of access is especially dangerous because it can be carried out by a staff member or an experienced attacker?
What type of attack could result from unauthorized logical access, causing a denial of service (DoS) on important business systems?
What is a flaw in a software component or system that allows an attacker to gain access through an exploit?
What type of vulnerability can be exploited through malware executed on a system by a user or directly by an attacker?
Which vulnerabilities can occur in any software running on a system, including the OS itself?
What vulnerabilities are similar to software vulnerabilities but can be even more damaging when present on servers?
Vulnerabilities in what systems can exist in the software used to provide services like FTP, SSH, and PHP?
Vulnerabilities in what type of system can be found in both the software it uses to provide services and in its OS?
What can occur during storage, transmission, or processing and is considered the greatest risk to system / application domains?
What is considered the greatest risk because the goal of system / application domains is to allow users to create, store, retrieve, and manipulate data?
What is the most common preventative measure against data loss?
What refers to the code of responsible behavior on the internet?
What is the basic rule of cyber ethics that states, “do not do something in cyberspace that you would consider wrong or illegal in everyday life”?
choices: Right to be inefficient if and where it defines our basic humanities

quizData.question: Which ethical framework was created by Gerd Leonhard?
Which manifesto provides a framework for global ethics in technology?
choices: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines

quizData.question: What is important to focus on in an era where machines will take on more human-like characteristics?
choices: Code of Ethics for Information Security Professionals

quizData.question: Which right ensures that people can be employed, use public services, buy things, and function in society without a requirement to deploy technology on or inside their bodies?
choices: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines

quizData.question: Which right allows individuals to choose to be slower than technology and not make efficiency more important than humanity?
quizData.answer: Right to be inefficient if and where it defines our basic humanities
choices: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines
Right to be inefficient if and where it defines our basic humanities

quizData.question: Which right ensures individuals can switch off connectivity, go dark on the network, and pause communication, tracking, and monitoring?
choices: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines

quizData.question: Which right allows individuals to avoid being identified and tracked while using a digital application or platform when it doesn’t pose a risk or impose itself on others?
choices: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines

quizData.question: Which right ensures companies or employers are not disadvantaged if they choose to use people instead of machines, even if it is more expensive and less efficient?
quizData.answer: Right to employ or involve people instead of machines
choices: Right to be inefficient if and where it defines our basic humanities
Right to employ or involve people instead of machines

quizData.question: What is derived from the Unified Framework for Information Security Professionals?
quizData.answer: Code of Ethics for Information Security Professionals
choices: Code of Ethics for Information Security Professionals

quizData.question: What core ethical value requires professionals to perform their duties under existing laws and exercise the highest moral principles?
What ethical value requires professionals to refrain from activities that would constitute a conflict of interest?
Which core ethical value requires professionals to act in the best interests of stakeholders consistent with the public interest?
Which ethical value requires professionals to act honorably, justly, responsibly, and legally in every aspect of their profession?
Which ethical value requires professionals to perform all duties in a fair manner and without prejudice?
Which ethical value requires professionals to exercise independent professional judgment to provide unbiased analysis and advice?
What ethical value states that when an opinion is provided, it should be noted as opinion rather than fact?
Which ethical value requires professionals to perform services diligently and professionally?
choices: Right to be inefficient if and where it defines our basic humanities

quizData.question: Which ethical value requires professionals to act with diligence and promptness in rendering service?
What ethical value states that professionals should render only those services they are fully competent and qualified to perform?
Which ethical value requires professionals to ensure that their work meets the highest professional standards?
Which ethical value requires professionals to support their colleagues and encourage their professional development?
Which ethical value requires professionals to keep stakeholders informed regarding the progress of their work?
Which ethical value requires professionals to refrain from conduct that would damage the reputation of the profession, colleagues, clients, and employers?
What ethical value requires professionals to report ethical violations to the appropriate governing body promptly?
